journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: A Retrospective Evaluation of Magnetic Resonance Imaging Effectiveness on Capitellar Osteochondritis Dissecans Among Overhead Athletes

article-meta.aff: †Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Hokkaido University School of Medicine, Sapporo, Japan
‡Department of Radiology, Hokkaido University School of Medicine, Sapporo, Japan
§Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Shinshu University School of Medicine, Matsumoto, Japan
Investigation performed at Hokkaido University School of Medicine, Sapporo, Japan

author-notes.corresp: *Norimasa Iwasaki, MD, PhD, Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Hokkaido University School of Medicine, Kita 15, Nishi 7, Sapporo 060-8638, Japan (e-mail: niwasaki@med.hokudai.ac.jp).

abstract.p: Background: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has been widely used to characterize osteochondritis dissecans (OCD) lesions. However, the usefulness of MRI for predicting fragment stability in OCD of the humeral capitellum (capitellar OCD) remains unclear.
Hypothesis: Preoperative MRI cannot accurately diagnose fragment instability of capitellar OCD in overhead athletes.
Study Design: Cohort study (diagnosis); Level of evidence, 1.

Methods: Twenty-seven male overhead athletes who had undergone surgery for capitellar OCD were included in the study. A single senior musculoskeletal radiologist blindly reviewed preoperative MRI of these OCD lesions. The radiologist reported the presence or absence of each of the 4 MRI signs indicating fragment instability as described by De Smet et al. The lesions were also classified according to the MRI staging system of Dipaola et al for characterizing the lesions. Intraoperative assessment of fragment stability was used as the gold standard. Sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), and negative predictive value (NPV) were determined for fragment instability as assessed by MRI.

Results: According to the MRI criteria by De Smet et al and the Dipaola et al staging system, 21 (78%) and 20 (74%) lesions were defined as unstable, respectively. The obtained results yielded a sensitivity of 89% and a specificity of 44% for diagnosing fragment instability using the De Smet et al MRI criteria and a sensitivity of 83% and a specificity of 44% using the Dipaola et al MRI staging system. The PPV and NPV for fragment instability were 76% and 67% using the De Smet et al criteria and 75% and 57% according to the Dipaola et al staging system, respectively. The overall correlation rate of Dipaola et al MRI and intraoperative stages was 41%.

Conclusion: Preoperative MRI cannot precisely diagnose fragment instability of capitellar OCD that requires operative treatments in overhead athletes. Especially, MRI indicating stable lesions is considered not to be useful in predicting intraoperative instability of capitellar OCD in this study population.

body.p: Osteochondritis dissecans (OCD) is an idiopathic lesion affecting an articular surface that involves separation of the cartilage and the subchondral bone. The majority of lesions in the elbow are found on the humeral capitellum (capitellar OCD). This lesion frequently occurs in overhead athletes such as baseball players.

The choice of treatment for capitellar OCD mainly depends on patient age and characteristics of the lesion, including size and fragment stability. In general, young patients with small and stable lesions are successfully treated by nonoperative treatments.3,24,26,28 On the other hand, adults having larger and unstable lesions seem not to respond to nonoperative methods.‖ Capitellar OCD has a high prevalence in young teenagers. In terms of patient age, this epidemiological evidence indicates favorable outcomes for healing OCD lesions. Therefore, determination of the characteristics of an OCD lesion is a crucial factor in selecting the appropriate treatment for an individual lesion.

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has been encouraged to characterize OCD lesions.4,5,22,23 Whereas the size and location of the lesion are easily determined, the fragment stability remains variable before surgery. Various MRI criteria for OCD stability have been reported in the literature.6,7,17 However, only a few studies have attempted to assess the usefulness of MRI criteria for characterizing OCD lesions.6,8,16,23 To our knowledge, there have been no studies focusing on this value in capitellar OCD in overhead athletes. Mechanical stress plays a critical role in determining fragment stability in OCD lesions. The excessive stress against the elbow joint during throwing activities results in fragment instability of capitellar OCD in overhead athletes. This leads to the hypothesis that the lesions that are predicted as stable by preoperative MRI would actually be defined as unstable by intraoperative investigations.

The purpose of this study was to retrospectively assess preoperative MRI features of capitellar OCD lesions that required operative treatments in overhead athletes and to correlate the MRI findings with intraoperative ones.

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: We identified 57 OCD lesions of 57 male overhead athletes from March 2001 to March 2011. Among them, 32 OCD lesions were treated by surgery during this period. Two patients were excluded because MRI scans had not been performed preoperatively. The MRI scans of the elbow were obtained for each patient. Twenty-seven of 30 MRI evaluations were performed using 2 kinds of 1.5-T magnets (Philips Medical Systems, Best, the Netherlands or Siemens, Erlangen, Germany). Two were performed with a 3.0-T magnet (Philips Medical Systems) and the remaining one with a 1.0-T magnet (GE Medical Systems, Milwaukee, Wisconsin). To eliminate bias of MRI conditions, we focused on the MRI scans obtained from the 1.5-T magnet machines. Twenty-six of the 27 patients were competitive baseball players, and the remaining one patient was a competitive soccer goalkeeper at the time of surgery. All patients were affected on the dominant side. Their mean age at the time of surgery was 14 years (range, 11-30 years). The age distribution is as follows: <16 years, 21 patients; 16 to 20 years, 5 patients; >20 years, 1 patient. All patients were prevented from doing their sports activities because of severe elbow pain. According to the radiographic classification of Takahara et al,20,26,27 anteroposterior and lateral radiographs showed a grade I lesion indicating localized flattening or radiolucency in 5 lesions, a grade II lesion indicating a nondisplaced fragment in 9 lesions, and a grade III lesion indicating a displaced or detached fragment in 13 lesions.

sec.title: MRI Examination
sec.p: Surface coils were used for all MRI examinations. Spin echo T2-weighted sagittal images were obtained in all patients. The T2-weighted images have a long repetition time (3000-5000 milliseconds) and a long echo time (80-90 milliseconds). Images were acquired with 3- to 4-mm slice thickness without an interslice gap, a field of view of 14 to 16 cm, and a matrix of 256 by 172 to 224. T1-weighted and fast spin echo T2-weighted fat-saturated images were also obtained. A single musculoskeletal radiologist with more than 10 years’ experience in joint MRI interpretation was blinded to patient data and intraoperative findings. The obtained MRI scans were reviewed by the radiologist. The radiologist documented the presence or absence of each of the 4 MRI signs indicating fragment instability as described by De Smet et al6,17 (Table 1). The presence of at least one sign indicates fragment instability. The OCD lesions were also classified according to the staging system of Dipaola et al7 for characterizing the lesions (Table 2). Stage III and IV lesions were considered unstable.

caption.p: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) Signs of Fragment Instability by De Smet et al6

tr.td: A thin, ill-defined or well-defined line of high signal intensity at the interface between the osteochondral lesion and the underlying bone
A discrete, round area of homogeneous high signal intensity beneath the lesion
A focal defect in the articular surface of the lesion
A high signal intensity line traversing the articular cartilage and subchondral bone plate into the lesion

caption.p: Staging System of Dipaola et al7 for Characterizing Osteochondral Lesionsa

tr.td: Irregularity and softening of articular cartilage, no definable fragment
Thickening of articular cartilage and low signal changes
Articular cartilage breached, definable fragment, not displaceable
Articular cartilage breached, low signal rim behind fragment indicating fibrous attachment
Articular cartilage breached, definable fragment, displaceable, but attached by some overlying articular cartilage
Articular cartilage breached, high signal changes behind fragment indicating synovial fluid between fragment and underlying subchondral bone

sec.title: Evaluation of Operative Findings
sec.p: The operation reports and intraoperative photographs were reviewed for each patient. Our indication for surgery included failure of more than 6 months of nonoperative treatment or plain radiograph and MRI evidence of unstable lesions. Basically, we provided nonoperative treatment for patients showing stable lesions by MRI. Two senior authors performed all operations. The operations were performed at an average of 26 days (range, 2-138 days) after MRI examination. With the patient under general anesthesia, we performed autologous osteochondral mosaicplasty for 24 lesions and drilling for 3 lesions using a posterior approach or the Kocher lateral approach.11,12,14 Based on direct inspection and palpation of the cartilage, OCD lesions were classified into 4 stages according to the International Cartilage Repair Society (ICRS) classification system (Table 3)10 and the staging system of Dipaola et al7 (Table 2). Stages I and II in both systems were considered stable, whereas stages III and IV were considered unstable.

caption.p: International Cartilage Repair Society Classification System of Osteochondritis Dissecans Lesions10

tr.td: Stable continuity, softened area covered by intact cartilage
Complete discontinuity, “dead in situ,” not dislocated
Dislocated fragment, loose within the bed or empty defect

sec.title: Correlation of MRI With Operative Findings
sec.p: Intraoperative assessment of fragment stability was used as the gold standard. Sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), and negative predictive value (NPV) were determined for fragment instability as assessed by MRI. Correlation of the MRI findings to intraoperative findings was also determined for lesion stage according to the staging system of Dipaola et al7 (Table 2).

sec.title: MRI Findings
sec.p: All 27 OCD lesions were located at the anterior aspect of the capitellum. Intra-articular loose bodies were found in 7 (26%) elbows. The mean maximum diameter of loose bodies was 10 mm (range, 7-13 mm). According to the MRI criteria for fragment instability by De Smet et al,6 21 of 27 (78%) lesions were classified as unstable lesions. Of the individual criteria for fragment instability, criterion 1 was most frequently observed (Table 4). Based on the Dipaola et al staging system,7 7 (26%) lesions and 20 (74%) lesions were defined as stable and unstable, respectively (Table 4 and Figures 1-3). Six of the 7 stable lesions were also classified as stable by De Smet et al.6 In this study, we performed nonoperative treatments only for these 7 patients. All patients with a stable lesion had elbow pain with pitching activities and restriction of elbow motion after nonoperative treatments. Mean range of elbow extension and flexion at surgery was 109° (extension, –13°; flexion, 125°) on the involved side, while the value was 148° (extension, 5°; flexion, 143°) on the contralateral side.

caption.p: Results of Magnetic Resonance Imaging Findingsa

tr.th: Criteria by De Smet et al6
Staging System of Dipaola et al7

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values expressed as number of lesions.

caption.p: A stable lesion in a 15-year-old male patient. A sagittal T2-weighted image demonstrates the thickening of articular cartilage and low signal changes at the subchondral region of the capitellum (white arrow). This corresponds to a stage I lesion according to the Dipaola et al staging system.7

An unstable lesion without a loose body in a 14-year-old male patient. In a sagittal T2-weighted image, articular cartilage of the capitellum is breached, with high signal changes behind the fragment (white arrow), indicating synovial fluid between the fragment and underlying subchondral bone. This corresponds to a stage III lesion according to the Dipaola et al staging system.7

An unstable lesion with a loose body in a 12-year-old male patient. A sagittal T2-weighted image shows a round area of homogeneous high signal intensity (large white arrow), indicating a focal defect in the cartilage and subchondral bone at the articular surface of the capitellum. There is a nodular lesion of low signal intensity (2 small white arrows), suggesting a loose body in the posterior radiohumeral joint space. This corresponds to a stage IV lesion according to the Dipaola et al staging system.7

sec.title: Operative Findings
sec.p: During operation, intra-articular loose bodies were observed in 11 (41%) elbows. The mean maximum diameter of loose bodies was 11 mm (range, 5-20 mm). Each of the 27 lesions was classified consistently using the Dipaola et al7 and ICRS staging system. According to both staging systems, 9 (33%) lesions in stage I or II and 18 (67%) lesions in stage III or IV were determined as stable and unstable lesions, respectively. There were 3 (11%) lesions in stage I, 6 (22%) lesions in stage II, 7 (26%) lesions in stage III, and 11 (41%) lesions in stage IV. While autologous osteochondral mosaicplasty was performed for the intraoperative unstable lesions or stable lesions with a 10-mm or larger diameter, drilling was chosen for the intraoperative stable lesions with less than a 10-mm diameter.

sec.title: Correlation of MRI and Operative Findings
sec.p: Table 5 summarizes the MRI findings and intraoperative findings. The obtained results yielded a sensitivity of 89% and a specificity of 44% for diagnosing fragment instability according to De Smet et al MRI criteria6 and a sensitivity of 83% and a specificity of 44% using the Dipaola et al MRI staging system.7 False-negative rates of the De Smet et al criteria6 and of the Dipaola et al staging system7 were 11% and 17%, respectively. The false-positive rate of both systems was 56%. The PPV and NPV for fragment instability were 76% and 67% according to the De Smet et al criteria6 and 75% and 57% using the Dipaola et al staging system,7 respectively.

caption.p: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) and Operative Findings Correlationa

tr.th: Criteria by De Smet et al6
Staging System of Dipaola et al7

fn.label: a
fn.p: Values expressed as number of lesions.

sec.p: The overall correlation rate of Dipaola et al7 MRI and intraoperative stages was 41%. Regarding the correlation of each MRI stage, no MRI stable lesions including stages I and II predicted intraoperative stages. On the other hand, MRI unstable lesions including stages III and IV predicted 4 of 7 (57%) lesions and 7 of 11 (64%) lesions, respectively.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Although MRI is sensitive and specific for diagnosing osteochondral lesions, there has still been debate regarding its usefulness for predicting fragment stability in OCD. To our best knowledge, this is the first study evaluating the usefulness of preoperative MRI in predicting the stability of capitellar OCD in overhead athletes at the time of operation. The current study in this patient cohort showed a sensitivity of 89% using the De Smet et al MRI criteria6 and 83% according to the Dipaola et al MRI staging system7 for diagnosing fragment instability. On the other hand, we found a much lower specificity (44%) in both systems. Heywood et al,8 using these MRI systems, demonstrated a sensitivity of 100% and a specificity of 15% for MRI diagnosis of unstable lesions in juvenile knee and talus OCD, supporting our results. In contrast, De Smet et al6 reported a sensitivity and specificity of 100% for MRI diagnosis of adult knee and ankle OCD. The mean age of patients was 14 years in the current study and 13 years in the study by Heywood et al,8 while that in the study by De Smet et al6 was 26 years. The dissimilarity in the specificity of MRI diagnosis may result from the difference in age of patient cohorts. A previous study suggested that MRI criteria for fragment instability have high specificity for adult (100% specificity) but not juvenile (11% specificity) knee OCD.17 This is consistent with our results in which specificity was found to be much lower.

Yonetani et al30 demonstrated that the histological findings of symptomatic juvenile-type stable OCD lesions in the knee have several similarities to those of adult-type unstable OCD lesions. Their most conclusive findings indicating fragment instability were an underlying instability at deeper layers of articular cartilage and poor healing at areas of separation. The NPV for fragment instability obtained in our study was 67% using the De Smet et al criteria6 and 57% according to the Dipaola et al staging system,7 suggesting a low predictive value. In addition, no MRI lesions in stages I and II correlated with intraoperative stages. As mentioned above, all patients except one were teenagers in this study. These results and low specificity indicate that preoperative MRI showing stable lesions is not reliable to predict intraoperative stability of the lesions in overhead athletes, especially teenagers. Although the study by Yonetani et al30 focused on knee lesions, their histological results support the current MRI results of capitellar OCD in our patient population. Collectively, these results lead to the consideration that symptomatic capitellar OCD lesions in young overhead athletes have histopathological instability despite stability indicated by preoperative MRI examination.

Mechanical stress acting on a joint has a profound effect on fragment stability in OCD lesions. Elbow OCD is mainly involved in the anterior part of the capitellum. Momma et al21 suggested that baseball pitching produces excessive stress against this region in the elbow. This excessive stress results in fragment instability of capitellar OCD in overhead athletes such as baseball players. Therefore, we speculate that patients classified as having a stable OCD by MRI are highly unlikely to have fragment stability at the time of operation.

One of the critical factors for selecting the treatment of OCD is the stability of fragments. Regarding capitellar OCD, nonoperative treatments provide favorable results when the lesion is stable.3,24,26,28 On the other hand, numerous surgical treatments such as fragment removal with or without drilling or curettage, abrasion chondroplasty, reattachment of the fragments, closed wedge osteotomy of the capitellum, autologous osteochondral grafts, or autologous chondrocyte implantation have been advocated for treating unstable lesions.¶ Our indication for surgery includes failure of more than 6 months of nonoperative treatment or plain radiographic and MRI evidence of unstable lesions. For intraoperative unstable lesions, we chose mosaicplasty, expecting repair with hyaline-like cartilage. Basically, drilling as a marrow-stimulating technique was performed for intraoperative stable lesions. However, in selecting a surgical procedure, lesion size should also be considered. Hurtig et al9 demonstrated that structural repair of hyaline cartilage occurred in 5-mm2 osteochondral defects by a marrow-stimulating technique. On the other hand, 15-mm2 osteochondral defects did not achieve structural repair using such a technique. Iwasaki et al11 reported that mosaicplasty provided excellent outcomes for capitellar OCD lesions with a 10-mm diameter. Therefore, we performed mosaicplasty for intraoperative stable lesions with a 10-mm or larger diameter in our series.

Capitellar OCD frequently occurs in competitive overhead athletes such as baseball players. Therefore, the principle for the treatment of this lesion, especially in young athletes, is to allow patients to return quickly to their previous level of sports activities and to prevent subsequent osteoarthritis. Towards achieving this goal, reliable preoperative MRI criteria for determining the fragment stability are required to select the adequate treatment options for each lesion. It is important for surgeons to understand the effectiveness of MRI diagnosis for fragment stability in capitellar OCD. As mentioned above, the effectiveness of MRI criteria for diagnosing instability of capitellar OCD lesions is relatively low compared with its reliability in adult knee or ankle OCD cases. Especially, MRI scans showing stable lesions do not accurately predict intraoperative fragment stability. Takahara et al26 stated that stable lesions of capitellar OCD had all of the 3 findings including an open capitellar growth plate, localized flattening or radiolucency of the subchondral bone, and good elbow motion. The cases having a capitellum with a closed growth plate or restriction of elbow motion were considered to be unstable. In the current study, all patients showing a stable lesion by MRI presented with elbow pain with pitching activities and limited elbow motion after nonoperative treatments. Three of the 7 stable lesions by Dipaola et al MRI criteria7 demonstrated intraoperative instability of fragments. From previous results and our current results, we may say that fragment stability of capitellar OCD is determined not only by MRI findings but also by clinical or physical findings such as elbow pain or restriction of elbow motion not responding to nonoperative treatments.

There are several limitations to this study. First, the current study was limited by the selection criteria for the study cohort. The patients selected here were based on having had operations. Such patients were considered to have advanced stages of OCD or long-standing symptoms. Therefore, the cohort represents only a part of the spectrum of capitellar OCD. The second limitation was the small number of patients with stable OCD determined by MRI. Approximately, only 26% of all OCD lesions were classified as stable by MRI examination. Third, MRI stability was determined by the interpretation of one musculoskeletal radiologist. Dipaola et al7 reported 100% agreement in the interpretation of MRI stability by 2 radiologists. This indicates that accurate MRI staging does appear to be reproducible without interexaminer variability. However, the interpretation by multiple radiologists could add strength to the current results. Finally, we did not directly compare the data obtained from capitellar OCD with those from the knee or talus OCD. Direct comparisons could more clearly show the characteristics of MRI diagnosis for fragment stability of capitellar OCD in overhead athletes.

In conclusion, MRI of capitellar OCD that requires operative treatments in overhead athletes averaging 14 years old showed a sensitivity of 89% and a specificity of 44% for diagnosing fragment instability using De Smet et al MRI criteria6 and a sensitivity of 83% and a specificity of 44% according to the Dipaola et al MRI staging system.7 The PPV and NPV were 76% and 67% using De Smet et al criteria6 and 75% and 57% according to the Dipaola et al staging system,7 respectively. The low values of specificity and NPV lead to the conclusion that MRI indicating stable lesions is of little benefit in predicting intraoperative stability of capitellar OCD that requires operative treatments in overhead athletes. The current study will provide useful information for surgeons in selecting appropriate treatment options and determining the optimal timing for performing surgery.

ack.p: The authors are especially thankful to Mr Mark Hamilton (Tokai University, Sapporo, Japan) for article preparation.

fn.p: The authors declared that they have no conflicts of interest in the authorship and publication of this contribution.
